Local government areas have responsibilities such as local roads, libraries, child care, community services and waste collection, whereas the state government retains responsibility for main roads, traffic control, public transport, policing, education, and major infrastructure project. There are 33 local government areas which are wholly or mostly within Greater <this city> as defined by the <this country>n Statistical Geography Standard.

<this city> is the location of the secondary official residences of the Governor-General of <this country> and the Prime Minister of <this country>, Admiralty House and Kirribilli House respectively. The Parliament of New South Wales sits in Parliament House on Macquarie Street. This building was completed in 1816 and first served as a hospital. The Legislative Council moved into its northern wing in 1829 and by 1852 had entirely supplanted the surgeons from their quarters. Several additions have been made to the building as the Parliament has expanded, but it retains its original Georgian façade. Government House was completed in 1845 and has served as the home of 25 Governors and 5 Governors-General. The Cabinet of <this country> also meets in <this city> when needed.
The highest court in the state is the Supreme Court of New South Wales which is located in Queen's Square in <this city>. The city is also the home of numerous branches of the intermediate District Court of New South Wales and the lower Local Court of New South Wales.In the past, the state has tended to resist amalgamating <this city>'s more populated local government areas as merged councils could pose a threat to its governmental power. Established in 1842, the City of <this city> is one such local government area and includes the CBD and some adjoining inner suburbs. It is responsible for fostering development in the local area, providing local services (waste collection and recycling, libraries, parks, sporting facilities), representing and promoting the interests of residents, supporting organisations that target the local community, and attracting and providing infrastructure for commerce, tourism, and industry. The City of <this city> is led by an elected Council and Lord Mayor.In federal politics, <this city> was initially considered as a possibility for <this country>'s capital city; the newly created city of Canberra ultimately filled this role. Seven <this country>n Prime Ministers have been born in <this city>, more than any other city, including first Prime Minister Edmund Barton and current Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.
Essential public emergency services are provided and managed by the State Government. Greater <this city> is served by:

New South Wales Police Force
New South Wales Ambulance
Fire and Rescue NSW

Infrastructure
Education
Education became a proper focus for the colony from the 1870s when public schools began to form and schooling became compulsory. By 2011, 90% of working age residents of <this city> had completed some schooling and 57% had completed the highest level of school. 1,390,703 people were enrolled in an educational institution in 2011 with 45.1% of these attending school and 16.5% studying at a university. Undergraduate or postgraduate qualifications are held by 22.5% of working age <this city> residents and 40.2% of working age residents of the City of <this city>. The most common fields of tertiary qualification are commerce (22.8%), engineering (13.4%), society and culture (10.8%), health (7.8%), and education (6.6%).
There are six public universities based in <this city>: The University of <this city>, University of New South Wales, University of Technology <this city>, Macquarie University, Western <this city> University, and <this country>n Catholic University. Five public universities maintain secondary campuses in the city for both domestic and international students: the University of Notre Dame <this country>, Central Queensland University, Victoria University, University of Wollongong, and University of Newcastle. Charles Sturt University and Southern Cross University, both public universities, operate secondary campuses only designated for international students. In addition, four public universities offer programmes in <this city> through third-party education providers: University of the Sunshine Coast, La Trobe University, Federation University <this country> and Charles Darwin University. 5.2% of residents of <this city> are attending a university. The University of New South Wales and the University of <this city> are ranked top 50 in the world, the University of Technology <this city> is ranked 133, while Macquarie University is ranked 237, and Western <this city> University is ranked 474.
<this city> has public, denominational, and independent schools. 7.8% of <this city> residents are attending primary school and 6.4% are enrolled in secondary school. There are 935 public preschool, primary, and secondary schools in <this city> that are administered by the New South Wales Department of Education. 14 of the 17 selective secondary schools in New South Wales are based in <this city>.Public vocational education and training in <this city> are run by TAFE New South Wales and began with the opening of the <this city> Technical College in 1878. It offered courses in areas such as mechanical drawing, applied mathematics, steam engines, simple surgery, and English grammar. The college became the <this city> Institute in 1992 and now operates alongside its sister TAFE facilities across the <this city> metropolitan area, namely the Northern <this city> Institute, the Western <this city> Institute, and the South Western <this city> Institute. At the 2011 census, 2.4% of <this city> residents are enrolled in a TAFE course.

Health
The first hospital in the new colony was a collection of tents at The Rocks. Many of the convicts that survived the trip from England continued to suffer from dysentery, smallpox, scurvy, and typhoid. Healthcare facilities remained hopelessly inadequate despite the arrival of a prefabricated hospital with the Second Fleet and the construction of brand new hospitals at Parramatta, Windsor, and Liverpool in the 1790s.Governor Lachlan Macquarie arranged for the construction of <this city> Hospital and saw it completed in 1816. Parts of the facility have been repurposed for use as Parliament House but the hospital itself still operates to this day. The city's first emergency department was established at <this city> Hospital in 1870. Demand for emergency medical care increased from 1895 with the introduction of an ambulance service. The <this city> Hospital also housed <this country>'s first teaching facility for nurses, the Nightingale Wing, established with the input of Florence Nightingale in 1868.Healthcare gained recognition as a citizen's right in the early 1900s and <this city>'s public hospitals came under the oversight of the Government of New South Wales. The administration of healthcare across <this city> is handled by eight local health districts: Central Coast, Illawarra Shoalhaven, <this city>, Nepean Blue Mountains, Northern <this city>, South Eastern <this city>, South Western <this city>, and Western <this city>. The Prince of Wales Hospital was established in 1852 and became the first of several major hospitals to be opened in the coming decades. St Vincent's Hospital was founded in 1857, followed by Royal Alexandra Hospital for Children in 1880, the Prince Henry Hospital in 1881, the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in 1882, the Royal North Shore Hospital in 1885, the St George Hospital in 1894, and the Nepean Hospital in 1895. Westmead Hospital in 1978 was the last major facility to open.

Transport
Roads
The motor vehicle, more than any other factor, has determined the pattern of <this city>'s urban development since World War II. The growth of low density housing in the city's outer suburbs has made car ownership necessary for hundreds of thousands of households. The percentage of trips taken by car has increased from 13% in 1947 to 50% in 1960 and to 70% in 1971. The most important roads in <this city> were the nine Metroads, including the 110 km (68 mi) <this city> Orbital Network. <this city>'s reliance on motor vehicles and its sprawling road network has been criticised by proponents of mass public transport and high density housing. The Light Horse Interchange in western <this city> is the largest in the southern hemisphere.There can be up to 350,000 cars using <this city>'s roads simultaneously during peak hour, leading to significant traffic congestion. 84.9% of <this city> households own a motor vehicle and 46.5% own two or more. Car dependency is an ongoing issue in <this city>–of people who travel to work, 58.4% use a car, 9.1% catch a train, 5.2% take a bus, and 4.1% walk. In contrast, only 25.2% of working residents in the City of <this city> use a car, whilst 15.8% take a train, 13.3% use a bus, and 25.3% walk. With a rate of 26.3%, <this city> has the highest utilisation of public transport for travel to work of any <this country>n capital city. The CBD features a series of alleyways and lanes that provide off-street vehicular access to city buildings and as well as pedestrian routes through city buildings.

Buses
Bus services today are conducted by private operators under contract to Transport for NSW. Integrated tickets called Opal cards operate on bus routes. In total, nearly 225 million boardings were recorded across the bus network NightRide is a nightly bus service that operate between midnight and 5am, also replacing trains for most of this period.

Trams and light rail
<this city> once had one of the largest tram networks in the British Empire after London. It served routes covering 291 km (181 mi). The internal combustion engine made buses more flexible than trams and consequently more popular, leading to the progressive closure of the tram network with the final tram operating in 1961. From 1930 there were 612 buses across <this city> carrying 90 million passengers per annum.In 1997, the Inner West Light Rail opened between Central station and Wentworth Park. It was extended to Lilyfield in 2000 and then Dulwich Hill in 2014. It links the Inner West and Darling Harbour with Central station and facilitated 9.1 million journeys in the 2016–17 financial year. A second, the CBD and South East Light Rail 12 km (7.5 mi) line serving the CBD and south-eastern suburbs opened partially in December 2019 and the remainder in April 2020. A light rail line serving Western <this city> has also been announced, due to open in 2023.

Trains
Established in 1906, Central station is the largest and busiest railway station in the state and is the main hub of the city's rail network. <this city> Trains is the suburban rail service. Its tracks form part of the New South Wales railway network. It serves 175 stations across the city and had an annual ridership of 359 million passenger journeys in 2017–18. <this city>'s railway was first constructed in 1854 with progressive extension to the network to serve both freight and passengers across the city, suburbs, and beyond to rural New South Wales. The main station is the Central railway station in the southern part of the CBD. In the 1850s and 1860s, the railway reached areas that are now outer suburbs of <this city>.<this city> Metro, a driverless rapid transit system separate from the suburban commuter network, commenced operation in May 2019 and will be extended into the city and down southwest by 2024 and through the inner west to Parramatta by 2030. It currently serves 13 stations. A line to serve the greater west is planned for 2026 and will include a station for the second international airport.

Ferries
At the time the <this city> Harbour Bridge opened in 1932, the city's ferry service was the largest in the world. Patronage declined from 37 million passengers in 1945 to 11 million in 1963 but has recovered somewhat in recent years. From its hub at Circular Quay, the ferry network extends from Manly to Parramatta.

Airports
<this city> Airport, officially "<this city> Kingsford-Smith Airport", is located in the inner southern suburb of Mascot with two of the runways going into Botany Bay. It services 46 international and 23 domestic destinations. As the busiest airport in <this country>, it handled 37.9 million passengers in 2013 and 530,000 tonnes of freight in 2011.
It has been announced that a new facility named Western <this city> Airport will be constructed at Badgerys Creek from 2016 at a cost of $2.5 billion. Bankstown Airport is <this city>'s second busiest airport, and serves general aviation, charter and some scheduled cargo flights. Bankstown is also the fourth busiest airport in <this country> by the number of aircraft movements. Port Botany has surpassed Port Jackson as the city's major shipping port. Cruise ship terminals are located at <this city> Cove and White Bay.

Environmental issues and pollution reduction
As climate change, greenhouse gas emissions and pollution have become a major issue for <this country>, <this city> has in the past been criticised for its lack of focus on reducing pollution, cutting back on emissions and maintaining water quality. Since 1995, there have been significant developments in the analysis of air pollution in the <this city> metropolitan region. The development led to the release of the Metropolitan Air Quality Scheme (MAQS), which led to a broader understanding of the causation of pollution in <this city>, allowing the government to form appropriate responses to the pollution. The 2019–20 <this country>n bushfire season significantly impacted outer <this city>, and consequently dramatically reduced the air quality of the <this city> metropolitan area leading to a smoky haze that lingered for many days throughout December. The air quality was 11 times the hazardous level in some days, even making it worse than New Delhi's, where it was also compared to "smoking 32 cigarettes" by Associate Professor Brian Oliver, a respiratory diseases scientist at the University of Technology <this city>.<this country>n cities are some of the most car-dependent cities in the world, especially by world city standards, although <this city>'s is the lowest of <this country>'s major cities at 66%. Furthermore, the city also has the highest usage of public transport in an <this country>n city, at 27%–making it comparable with New York City, Shanghai and Berlin. Despite its high ranking for an <this country>n city, <this city> has a low level of mass-transit services, with a historically low-density layout and significant urban sprawl, thus increasing the likelihood of car dependency. Strategies have been implemented to reduce private vehicle pollution by encouraging mass and public transit, initiating the development of high density housing and introducing a fleet of 10 new Nissan LEAF electric cars, the largest order of the pollution-free vehicle in <this country>. Electric cars do not produce carbon monoxide and nitrous oxide, gases which contribute to climate change. Cycling trips have increased by 113% across <this city>'s inner-city since March 2010, with about 2,000 bikes passing through top peak-hour intersections on an average weekday. Transport developments in the north-west and east of the city have been designed to encourage the use of <this city>'s expanding public transportation system.
The City of <this city> became the first council in <this country> to achieve formal certification as carbon-neutral in 2008. The city has reduced its 2007 carbon emissions by 6% and since 2006 has reduced carbon emissions from city buildings by up to 20%. The City of <this city> introduced a Sustainable <this city> 2030 program, with various targets planned and a comprehensive guide on how to reduce energy in homes and offices within <this city> by 30%. Reductions in energy consumption have slashed energy bills by $30 million a year. Solar panels have been established on many CBD buildings in an effort to minimise carbon pollution by around 3,000 tonnes a year.The city also has an "urban forest growth strategy", in which it aims to regular increase the tree coverage in the city by frequently planting trees with strong leaf density and vegetation to provide cleaner air and create moisture during hot weather, thus lowering city temperatures. <this city> has also become a leader in the development of green office buildings and enforcing the requirement of all building proposals to be energy-efficient. The One Central Park development, completed in 2013, is an example of this implementation and design.

Utilities
Obtaining sufficient fresh water was difficult during early colonial times. A catchment called the Tank Stream sourced water from what is now the CBD but was little more than an open sewer by the end of the 1700s. The Botany Swamps Scheme was one of several ventures during the mid-1800s that saw the construction of wells, tunnels, steam pumping stations, and small dams to service <this city>'s growing population.The first genuine solution to <this city>'s water demands was the Upper Nepean Scheme which came into operation in 1886 and cost over £2 million. It transports water 100 km (62 mi) from the Nepean, Cataract, and Cordeaux rivers and continues to service about 15% of <this city>'s total water needs. Dams were built on these three rivers between 1907 and 1935. In 1977 the Shoalhaven Scheme brought several more dams into service.The state-owned corporation WaterNSW now manages eleven major dams: Warragamba one of the largest domestic water supply dams in the world, Woronora, Cataract, Cordeaux, Nepean, Avon, Wingecarribee Reservoir, Fitzroy Falls Reservoir, Tallowa, the Blue Mountains Dams, and Prospect Reservoir. Water is collected from five catchment areas covering 16,000 km2 (6,178 sq mi) and total storage amounts to 2.6 TL (0.6 cu mi). The <this city> Desalination Plant came into operation in 2010. WaterNSW supplies bulk water to <this city> Water, a state-owned corporation that operates water distribution, sewerage and storm water management services across greater <this city>.
The two distributors which maintain <this city>'s electricity infrastructure are Ausgrid and Endeavour Energy. Their combined networks include over 815,000 power poles and 83,000 km (52,000 mi) of electricity cables. Submarine communications cable systems in <this city> include the <this country>–Japan Cable, Telstra Endeavour and the Southern Cross Cable, which link <this country> and countries in the Pacific, such as Japan, Fiji, New Zealand and the US, among many others.
